reviewText:
I think it's time I write my first real review of a steam game--and I'm happy to make it this one.

Victoria II has a steep learning curve, but if you open yourself up: it's easy and addicting.

The attraction to Victoria II is not its asthetics, it's its offering to let you take on a whole new history.

Victoria II plops you into 1836, right before the crowning of Queen Victoria and at the height of the British Empire. The Hapsburg Monarchy still rules the Austrian Empire and Germany is still divided into many small states. The Tsars rule over the Russian Empire that still seeks its greatest extents and America is not even 100 years old.  France emerges from the Napoleonic wars in defeat but a new spring is just around the corner. The Ottoman Empire is the sick man of Europe" but with the right leadership can embrace the new age with renewed vitality.

And even more nations await emergence: Japan
recommended:
and of course the oncoming rush for Africa will change the face of the world.

Any nation is playable in Victoria II. Even more can be released or formed. Almost every game is different.

War isn't the focus here. Though it is an intriguing aspect.

What will draw you in: is the diplomacy.


Now that may sound boring but pay in mind the dynamics here. Although the great powers rule and may keep you in-check
hoursPlayed: playing as one (or better-yet
voteText: using them to your advantage to gain power) will keep you thrilled.\n\nThe Great powers of the time compete to influence other
helpfulPercent: smaller nations. Intricate webs of alliances and spheres can easily turn a localized conflict into a world war.\n\nCrises over disputed territories can cause Great Powers to go at-odds
votesHelpful: lobbying other powers to join their side in the tension-packed period where the world can drift into destructive war.\n\nLater in the game
votesTotal: these can mean "great wars" were defeat can mean total decimation.\n\nIn fact
votesFunny:
each country is only one war-gone-bad from collapse.

Compete to establish puppet states who will obey your every whim.
Sphere nations to earn off their industry and almost garantee their support.
Colonize the unsettled worlds of Africa
column16:
and North America.
Keep other nations from doing the same.

Also there are different civilization levels. Primitive
column19: and civilized. Depending on what stage your in impacts your ability to function as a state as your technology will be way behind
column20: you won't be able to build industries
column21:
ect. until you "westernize" and join the world as a modern-style nation-state.

This alone can be fun as you struggle to survive in the old ways or fight against your own people who resist your attempts to change their very culture.

Warfare itself is more fleshed-out than initially realized. Your armies' ability to do recconassaince
column23: and fight in battle is dependent upon their specilized unit makeup and perhaps too-often ignored: their generals.\n\nAn army of 80
column24: 000 draftees can be thrawted by a smaller
column25:
diverse professional army and an excellently-chosen general who can earn fame by winning battles which will in-turn provide greater bonuses.

Naval power is a MUST to establish yourself as a colonial power. Blockades can WRECK your trade. And just as with armies: diversity and excellent Admirals can win you the day.


Trade itself can be largely ignored and should be automated unless you feel otherwise inclined.

Politics within your own country can grab your attention.

The availible government types are:

Democracy
HM's Government
Prussian Constitutionalism
Absolute Monarchy
Proletarian Dictatorship
Fascist Dictatorship
Borgeouseis Dictatorship
Presidential Dictatorship.

To better understand this
column26: the political party in power decides your trade policy
column30: ability to intervene/control factories and industry
column31:
and your upper house (legislative body) will decide what reforms you can impliment.

Democracies are governments where the party in power is elected and they guide policy until the next election.

HM's Government are the same but you have the ability to change the government in power (though reforms will require the appropriate members in said upper house).

Prussian Constitutionalism is this wierd grey-area between Absolute Monarchies and Democracies though usually have elections.

Absolute Monarchies have no elections (which by the way are totally annoying and only nudge public opinion especially in large countries) and can choose the ruling party.

Then come the dictatorships which are usually single-party.

THE BEST PART IS YOU GET DIFFERENT FLAGS DEPENDING ON YOUR GOVERNMENT

SOMETIMES DIFFERENT NAMES.

An example is Mexico who
column33: will change to the Empire of Mexico.\n\nThe United Kingdom will change to Great Britain if a democracy or the People's Commonwealth if a proletarian dictatorship
column34:
These will also cause flag changes.

Rebels will lobby for reform changes or even radical government change. Sometimes you might want them to win. There's nothing wrong with letting the generals plot a dictator's downfall.

Now finally mods which really can give a lot of replayability to this game.

Mods are relatively easy to get though are not taken from the steam workshop but from websites like Moddb.

These mods have infinite potential offering different timelines
column38:
new alternate timelines.


Some even add events to the more minor nations to make them more dynamic to play.

OH
ONE MORE THING

Multiplayer IS possible
column40:
it's awesome with friends.

You can coordinate to carve up continents for your empires.
You can plot against each-other. A great game is Austria and Prussia competing for dominance.

Here's how we do it:
Download Hamachi which will allow you to create a network your friends can connect to.
They will use the Hamachi-provided IP address the host of the network has to connect to your game.

It's advised to put the game to save often. We do half-years.

Make sure you verify the integrity of your game cache every time you play together. And close out of the game entirely if someone crashes and do so again just to be sure.

You MUST have the same version to operate.

If you want to load saves
column41:
the host (and only the host) needs to disable their firewalls.

another thing: the Host should host the hamachi network AND the multiplayer game.
We haven't tried mods yet.

To conclude this review
column42: make sure you invest into this game (and hope someday for another Paradox game that picks up where this one leaves off--1939 or somewhere around that era). It may seem overwhelming at first
column43:
but attack and google around if you're lost. Usually you can find a forum post where they have your question or you can start your own.

Find friends to join the game with you.

Take pictures. f12.

"

reviewText: Victoria II is a truly unique grand strategy game, one that goes in depth into everything. While some may find the economics system confusing, it can be handled in a timely manner by moving a few sliders around, or in the long run, adjusting every tiny thing as you go along. Wars, while an important part of the game and expanding your nation, are not the main focus of the game, but rather keeping a stabilized country. To go to war is not only to expand your borders, but to expand your economy and influence in a region. Civil wars and revolts may occur if you are not in a stable position, unfortunately caused because of liberals, your lack of assimilation in a region, or the people of your proud nation want changed policies.\n\nI would recommend this great grand strategy game to anyone who enjoys a game of its type, be it a fascination with the countries in it, the type of game, or both.

reviewText:
The first nation I chose to play as was Russia, which proved to be a terrible choice for obvious reasons. Then I decided to go with a smaller but not highly vulnerable underdog nation to ease my learning curve, and went with Japan. After numerous decades and a dozen or so hours of playtime, not only had I civilized and modernized all of Japan and brought forth a new era of industrial supremacy, but I skyrocketed the nation to the rank of a Great Power.

By the 1880's, after multiple successful wars with Russia, Korea, China, and several other countries, Japan nearly tripled in size and had become the 5th greatest nation in the world, right behind Russia. At first I was overcome by the sheer joy of success, as Japan was ranked third in industrial power and was one of the most prestigious nations in the world. Then as my economy began to slow down, my income was turning negative for the first time in over a decade as factories closed and unemployment jumped. I began to raise taxes, cut my military and navy, and then I began to raise doubts about my countries future. Unfortunately, my doubts were realized.

As the century turned and the 1900's began, my economy neared depression-level and the national debt was adding up, growing political divisions were threatening the countries stability, and new factions were rising up demanding things like workers rights and calling for a liberal government. The tension came to a boiling point in Pyongyang, where nearly twenty thousand Korean rebels rose up in arms against Japanese rule and were completely annihilated before they could even take two steps forward. At what seemed like the worst time, I was plunged into a war between Germany and Russia, as Germany was the #1 world super power and was my closest ally. Actually, Germany was one of very few countries willing to ally with me as my infamy was a little too high from the Japanese conquests in Korea, China, and Russia. More great powers suddenly joined the war, and it became known as the Great War. My forces were diminished from the get-go, and my allies were too busy fighting their own battles. Before long I was utterly decimated by an invasion force of Russian and French forces and rage quit.

I still haven't turned the tide, but nonetheless I rate this game 10/10.

reviewText:
Paradox Interactive must be the masters of Strategy games. This is one of their finest. Victoria II is set in the Victorian Era in the 19th and early 20th century. From 1836 to 1936, you have 100 years to lead a nation to triumph. There are no official goals in the game. You make the goals. But the de-facto prospect is making a country into an economic or military superpower. Some nations like Great Britain are already big at the start, but playing a small nation like Greece can give you the opportunity to give it a time it never saw. That's right. You're not playing history. You're re-writing it. Every little thing you do in the game can have big, unintentional outcomes. Doing something in North America might somehow cause a war in Europe. You never know.

This is just how fun Victoria II is for history buffs. You can play unlikely countries and turn them into a colonial superpowers. I played Ireland and gave it African colonies. I claimed the island of Hawaii for Mexico, preventing the USA from annexing it in actual history. I played the Confederate States of America and fought hard for it's independence and giving it colonies around the world. There is just so much you can do. So many opportunities.

But while that sounds like a lot of fun, you're going to have to work hard to achieve your goals. This game has a huge learning curve. In fact, I was almost turned off by the game when playing it for the first time because of how complex it was. But learning is the fun part. I didn't spend a lot of time with the tutorial. I just played around and learned as played. Right now, I know how this game works. But I'm still learning. As I said before, you have to work hard. There's a lot of things to do when managing a country. Here are those things.

- You have to manage taxes and government spending. Some countries might have to rely on heavy taxing on the poor, middle and rich if the government lacks a lot of money in their bank. You might also have to cut down on military and infastructure spending to rake in cash. If you are in serious decline of money, you can borrow funds from the bank. But you will have to repay those debts. Some nations have the population and profits to not worry about funding. But other small nations will.
-Economy management. You might have to open factories to gain profits. Depending on your country's economic policy. You can open factories or let the AI capitalists do them for you. These factories needs craftsmen and whatever resources the factories need. And let's talk about that next.
-Resources. This is the fun part. Let's face it. Some nations don't have everything they need. A small country like Texas (which lacks a big population and resources) might have to go to war and conquer weaker nations to prosper. Colonies help boost the resources and pops you need.
-War. It's not the primary focus of the game, but it's a whole lot of fun. War is not the goal. War helps your goals. As mentioned before, you might need to start a war to conquer a nation/colony for more resources. Or you might go to war to establish a puppet-state which acts like a permanent alliance. Whatever suits your agenda, War can help you.
-Diplomacy. Okay, it's not really the intriguing part but politics and international relations is what makes things more interesting in Vic 2. If you want to survive, you might need to make a few friends when making more enemies.
- Technological advancement. You got a century to run a country and while years go by, new technologies will be available for you to develop. This is how a country will improve and become stronger. Military, Naval, Commerce, Culture and Industry are the 5 tech trees you can develop on the way. Culture, industry and Commerce might be important for nations that are just sitting around, but warmongers might like Military and Naval much more better. All 5 of the trees are important however, so don't try and pick the military ones only.
-Politics. Oh man, sometimes the hardest part of running the nation is how to deal with your citizens. If you're a democracy, people are gonna have vote for their favorite political party. And each political party that could be in power, will affect your nation. Hell, if you're population manages to vote the Communist Party in, you might accidently have caused your country to be a dictatorship. If you're not managing your country well, rebellions can happen and if you can't fight off the rebellions with your military, you might be running a new government soon. You can also make political and social reforms like voting policies or whether or not the minimum wage should be lower.
-Colonization. This is the best part of Victoria II. There are several uncolonized parts of the world. Not that they lack populations but that there are no established nations there. Australia & New Zealand are mostly uncolonized with the exception of a few provinces. But most likely, Britain will do inevitably colonize them. North America will be the only continent to be fully colonized quickly. There are unclaimed land that the United States, Mexico or Britain will grab before the 1850's. But the glory of colonization occurs in Africa. Most of the continent is unclaimed. There's only a few nations and small colonial settlements that exist.
-Modernization. Europe, in this time period has the technology that is top of the line. So most of the world is somewhat behind compared to Europe. So if you're playing a country in Africa or Asia, you will want to spend some time modernizing. Japan is the pretty much the only country in the game that modernizes so quickly. But not only that, you get to turn Japan into a colonial superpower faster than any other country that hasn't westernized.

While I did not mention everything, there is just so much you can do. Key historical events like the American Civil War can occur when the time is ready. You can also install mods that improve the gameplay experience. The New Nations Mod adds countries that the developers should have added before.

I definitely recommend Victoria II for anyone who is into strategy games and history in general.

10/10

reviewText:
Oh God, I can't believe that I haven't reviewed this game yet.

As I write this, I have 437.3 hrs on record--making this the most played game in my library.
-----
Victoria II is a game that starts in 1836 and ends in 1936. So 100 years of gameplay. This is one of Paradox's faster paced games, as years can go by very quickly depending on the speed and how you manage that time. In my case, I only play as challenging nations like: Texas, Hawaii, Bali, Nejd, Ionian Islands, Mecklenburg, and Cuba. I find joy in trying to turn a small nation into a successful empire. This usually takes many years to do, however.

- Population: The main difference I can list right off the bat, compared to other Paradox titles, is that this game focuses on your population. Your population is comprised of: Farmers, labourers, craftsmen, soldiers, officers, clerks, slaves, and other professions. Naturally, if you want armies, you need soldiers. If you want to become rich, you must employ more workers into your factories, and more labourers into the fields. It's very important to keep your population content with your government, or they may revolt. Many may find revolts tedious and annoying, but I for one believe that revolts are one of the most crucial parts to the game. And I will explain why momentarily.

- Politics: While a game like Hearts of Iron III has politics, there isn't much depth to it. You really have little control over what political party rises in Hearts of Iron III. In Victoria 2, your population plays a major role in what political party is elected (assuming that they are allowed to vote!) This game contains 7 different political factions: Liberals, conservatives, anarcho-liberals, reactionaries, socialists, communists, and fascists. Of the 7, I always go socialist--as I am very familiar with this system. Along with the political parties, you can combine this with different types of governments. There are monarchies, democracies, dictatorships (and proletarian dictatorships for the communists.) The best part about government changes, is that the flag of a nation will change as well. For example; if Germany turned into a proletarian dictatorship, they would receive the flag of the DDR. While if they turned into a fascist dictatorship, they acquire the flag of the Third Reich (Kind of...) I love the political aspect of this game, and it is likely the one reason I constantly play this game.

- Revolts: As I said, these are usually annoying to you in two ways. 1. They may be attacking your country. 2. They may be attacking a puppet/ally, and thus will tear your ties with that nation if overthrown. Now, on the other hand, rebels are truly what makes the game interesting. The Russians are defeated BADLY in a war, and communist rebels rise. They overthrow the Russian Empire and form the Soviet Union. If you ask me, that's pretty damn interesting! After 80 years of seeing the same old Russian Empire, it's nice seeing them throw out the red color and put on the classic hammer and sickle. How about Scottish rebels? Is it not interesting to see Scotland gain independence from the United Kingdom through violent means? There's both pros and cons to rebels. I personally have NO PROBLEM with rebels, ever. I just choose the socialist party loyalty national focus on my nation, let my nation turn more red, and I seem to be in good hands. Otherwise, if the rebels want to fight, I will go Rocky IV on them. So in other words... I love rebels.

- The scramble for Africa: This is such a fun part of the game, but I feel that it mainly improved with the addition of the Heart of Darkness DLC. Throughout your game, you will notice that Africa is a mere wasteland of uncolonized land. There is generally nothing interesting that surrounds Africa until the 1870s, when the doors are unlocked and all great and secondary powers are given the green light to begin colonization. It's nothing short of a big race. Everyone wants to get their hands on the most land, and if you plan things out accordingly (like perhaps annexing Liberia before 1870) you can form a massive African empire. What you choose to do with your newly acquired African land is up to you. Use it for its resources, or release it all into one giant satellite nation. Overall, this is always an exciting event of any campaign.

- Technological advancements: In 1870, everyone but the primitive nations essentially start off with the option to build infantry or cavalry, and that's about it. As for navy, you can build anything as simple as a clipper transport or frigate. As time goes on, however, and you research more, you will acquire much more advanced types of infantry and warships. I am personally a big fan of the tanks that are available in the early 20th century. More than tanks, however, I love the battleships. Nothing is more satisfying than having a battleship and spotting an enemy fleet of mere commerce raiders. It's simply too funny of a battle. Unfortunately, technology is not my favorite aspect of this game. I much prefer Hearts of Iron's system and I really wish they had implemented something similar in this game. While Victoria II has a wide variety of technology branches, I simply wish the decisions I make for research was as dynamic as it was in Hearts of Iron. I'm crossing my fingers that next time around, Victoria III (Not announced YET) will give you the option to completely focus on a specific part of the game. Considering I'm pro-navy, I would love if I could continue to improve the strengths of my battleships.

In conclusion, I love this game so much. Whenever I look at all of the other grand strategy games on Steam, I contemplate, and I cry. I leap into bed and soak my pillow with tears, understanding that there will never be another day where such a worthy game will hit the stores. ...but I'm just kidding. I love Europa Universalis IV a lot too.

This game is currently 75% off until September 8. A fair piece of warning, though. This review was written through the eyes of someone with both A House Divided and Heart of Darkness. While the vanilla game is $5, I highly recommend just grabbing the other two DLC to ensure that you feel you made a satisfying purchase.

reviewText:
To keep the review short, this game will challenge you.

In order to enjoy it, as I do, you either need to be a large history fan of the era (1830's to 1910's) or a great fan of grand strategy games, Paradox games in particular.

Victoria II is not held as highly rated as EU or CK2 and I can see why as it seems a lot more limiting. HOWEVER saying that it (just as with all paradox games I have played) is a stunningly well made and authentic title and has improved hugely from the first Victoria game. It can be complex as it is highly political but you soon learn to just build a ton of factories and help the capitalists and aristocrats if you want to succeed.

A political grand strategy game not a military one. Possibly the best of its kind. Fantastic game highly recommended.

reviewText:
Victoria 2, yet another Grand Strategy Game produced by Paradox Interactive, however unlike Hearts of Iron taking you through the second world war, Victoria 2 takes you through the Victorian era, a period of colonization, nationalism, industrialization, and westernization. You play literally as any country from 1836, from the United States of Central America to the Free City of Kraków, and guide it through the Industrial era and the Victorian era.

Forge your destiny as you guide your nation through 100 years of industrialization, war, and colonization, vie for Great Power status and sign Alliances that at a split second, could be aimed at you, survive anarcho-liberal uprisings and anti-western partisans as you try to westernize as Japan. Along with nations that already exist, there are some that are relasable or formable; defeat the Russian Empire as Sweden and form Scandinavia, release Scotland from the United Kingdom and form your own Empire.  Play as Prussia and Form The North German Confederation, and then Germany, play as Two Sicilies and form Italy, play as France and become a giant blob, the choice is yours, for 100 years you are free to achieve your goals, and watch the world change, not even the AI choose the same path each time.

Will the Communist Rebels in France take Paris and install their own government? Will the Anarcho-Liberal anarchists take power in Russia? Will America spread burgers throughout the world? Will the Soviet Union fall to Democratic Germany, will Fascist France continue its rivalry with Communist Britain? Will Australia become a Communist Global power and vie with Democratic New Zealand? Or will the Democratic Rebels in the West stutter the Aussies' Chances? Will the Irish Rebels beat back the British units and declare independence? Will Liberia colonize all of Africa before the scramble even starts? Will Texas annex Mexico? Will the California Republic invade Hawaii? Will the CSA end the Civil war with a Stalemate? Will the CSA come begging to the USA again for Union? Will Poland into space? Will Bolivia into Coastline? Will Switzerland sit on its bum and watch the world go by? Will China industrialize and defeat the Western industry? Will Russia keep Alaska? Will Jews elect a facist party in Israel? I'm not certain, but all of this is possible in Victoria 2.

Pro's:
+Balanced combat, as well as a nice amount of units (not too many, not too little) and provide nice costumization of forces
+Great powers and secondary powers make the game feel more real
+ Neat political system (upperhouse, elections and reforms)
+ Factory system
+ Attention to detail: Each country has its own flags for Monarchy, Republic, Fascist and Communist. And most countries have flavour events.
+ You can change history

Con´s:
- Steep learning curve

Overall rating: 14/15 (Must own for history nerds and strategy gamers)

reviewText:
Good things about this game:

+ Play as Brazil
+ play as the largest portuguese colony (Brazil)
+ play as the largest south american country (Brazil)
+ play as the largest portuguese speaking country (Brazil)
+ play as the country that has the greatest state of all time (Minas Gerais > Minas Tirith + Minas Morgul) which is Brazil
+ play as the country of Dom Pedro II (Brazil)
+ play as the country of six letters that starts with a B and ends with a L
+ play as Brazil during the war of the farrapos, during the cisplatine war and during the paraguayan war (events with the pop demand mod)

Bad things about this game:
- Cant play with Brazil twice at the same time. But then hows that possible?! O.o

-------------

Now really, this is the best paradox game, much better than CK2, HoI3 and EU3/4. If you buy it, play with the Pop demand mod, which makes it really better and adds hundreds of events for pretty much every country (including Brazil :D). Also, like pretty much every paradox game, you kinda have to buy it with all the expansions, the last one (heart of darkness) is very good and the crisis system is pretty AWESOME. This game is the perfect game if you want to reenact the wars of the last half of the 19th century to the first world war. (after that, obviously go with Hearts of Iron 3). The map in here is also way better than, for example, Hoi3. I cant stand to watch South America in HoI3, its like a kid had made it. In here its much more alike.

reviewText:
When you first launch Victoria II, there could be a file exception, of which solution can be found here.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
初次启动维多利亚2可能会在初始化地图逻辑（initialising map loigc）时，
弹出文件异常（File exception：Exception in: virtualfilesystem.cpp, line: 662.）

解决办法：首先定位维多利亚2游戏地图缓存目录（..\SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Victoria 2\map\cache），然后删除目录中的所有文件，但保留空目录cache；
然后定位到（文档\Paradox Interactive\Victoria II），删除该目录中的所有文件；
接着重新启动游戏，祝你好运。

reviewText:
Victoria II is a grand strategy game from Paradox Interactive, the same company that created Europa Universalis, Crusader Kings, and Hearts of Iron. The game is easy to learn to play, but challenging to master. It features very complex inner-workings that can take a very long time to fully understand, but players willing to tackle the challnges this game brings will be entertained for hundreds of hours.

In a nutshell, Victoria II gives the player command of any country on earth in the century from 1836 to 1936. It is a game based on history, but it is not an historical simulation. Expect weird things to occur, like a communist revolution in Texas, a globe-spanning Greek Empire, or a fascist Brunei launching devastating wars of conquest in every continent.

The player's role in the game is to ensure their country's success or dominance. Like other Paradox games, you cannot win" or "lose". There are no standardized goals
recommended: you  do whatever you want to see your country and its population thrive (or collapse into total anarchy and civil war
hoursPlayed: if that's your thing). You can use any number of tools to see your country grow
voteText: from cajoling other states into joining your "sphere of influence"
helpfulPercent: to forcing them in at the tip of your sword; from encouraging immigration to your lands
votesHelpful: to conquering more populated lands; from building titanic industrial machines
votesTotal: to dispersing protesting strikers dragging down your titanic industrial machine. Warfare forms the core of the game
votesFunny: with economic and political concerns filling in the peacetime. You'll often find yourself invading other territories to secure access to an important resource your factories need

column17: but the online community will help you overcome most of the impediments. There is also still something of a modding community

reviewText:
I really hated this game and Europa Universalis when I first got them.  I wanted to jump in, murder all of the nonbelievers and create the world under my iron fist.  This is not that type of game.  Even though Civ and Total War pretend they've made improvements in diplomacy, they still really only come down to killing everyone else.
You will not jump into this game and eradicate the lesser countries.  What you can do... is subjugate them under your nation, push your influence, and try and form the nations of Italy, Germany, etc... out of the smaller city states.  Or if your citizens live in a state owned by another nation (such as Greece and the Aegis Islands being owned by the Ottomans), you can through some sneakery diplomacy take them with no bloodshed, or even get the major world powers to do the dirty work for you if you need some early weak undeveloped nations to colonize but lack the resources to mobilize yourself.
There's a definite learning curve, but luckily there's Youtube to show you what the heck you're doing.

Now that I've given it a second chance and know better what to expect from it, I definitely see what everyone meant about this being the 'big boy game' that you move to when you grow up from Civ (not that I dislike Civ at all).
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is without a doubt one of those games that you can simply lose yourself in for hours upon hours, if not days. I look at how many hours I've poured into this game and I scare myself every single time, because it's mindboggling. I love this games mechanics and overall point: shaping history as you would like it. There is something about the United Kingdom invading the United States and taking New England from them that just makes me laugh at how different things would and could be. The only complaints I have with this game, and the accompanying DLCs, is that the game is not taken far enough in some aspects, and too far in others. Also, the tutorial is rather dull. When it comes to political, social, and diplomatic mechanics, the game has not been taken far enough. Adding several mechanics, like they have in several MODs I have seen and heard about, as well as what Creative Assembly did in EUIV, would improve the game greatly. The Trade tab interface, is rather pointless, and if anything shouldn't be there. If it is retained, it should be further mainstreamed in how it operates, but the amount of goods, should be further expanded. All in all, I am impressed with this game, very, very impressed. I give it a strong 9.25/10, and with the enhancements I mentioned, it would be an immediate 10/10.

reviewText: Victoria II (and its expansion packs) is one of my all-time favorite games. The depth of the game is extraordinary; you can choose to follow a nation's path through history or change it to your liking. The diplomacy, economics, and warfare in the game feel very realistic, especially as the game progresses into the modern era. The learning curve is steep but the process is quite entertaining. A House Divided and Heart of Darkness offer so many improvements to the game, such as the international crisis system and the ability to begin the campaign at the outbreak of the American Civil War. In summary, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys grand strategy games or just have an interest in history (or changing it).

reviewText:
Victoria II, a game which introduced me to Grand Strategy. (This review is abit long hue hue)

The game starts off at the peak of the industrial revolution. The world is pushed into this great leap that no one has ever seen before. Smoke rises from the newly built factories. Railroad tracks can be seen in almost every part of the globe, connecting city after city. Warfare has now changed into a more deadlier way. The old wooden ships are now replaced by steam-propelled warships protected by iron or steel plates. It is the early 19th century, and thus a new age is born.

Victoria II is a game for those who love grand strategy games and (most importantly) history. This game will blow your mind because of the depth of gameplay that the dev's put into this game.

Diplomacy, History, Politics, Warfare, Technology, and even Economy can be seen in this game. Every player has his/her own style of play. You can play as Great Britain and just colonize every part of the world that is not colonized yet. You can be Prussia and unite all the german people into one banner. You can be Denmark and try to make Scandinavia for yourself. You can be any nation you want in this game's time period.

This is one of those games that makes you think hard on what to do next. Maybe rise the taxes? Make war to all your neighbors? Take on the Great Powers of the World and try to make them step down from their outstanding greatness? Forge an empire which will humiliate the United Kingdom? Make the richest nation of the world? Isolate yourself from wars or be neutral, like Switzerland? Maintain a monarchy that controls the whole country? It is up to you on how you play your country in Victoria II.

Im giving this game a 9/10. Game is amazing but there are times that the AI is just a ♥♥♥♥♥.
Grab this game now or in a steam sale. I suggest you get the complete version of the game because its complete and has the awesome uniforms that germany used before and during the years of World War One (which I personally love).

reviewText: Looking for a game based on the age of Industrialization? One that can go far through the history of the past up until modern times? Well you've found it here; an intense, entertaining, and highly submersive nation simulator. Fight through wars of epic proportions with realistic environments, exploitation of the terrain, and of technological advances to gain the edge on your enemy. Not to mention the cultural influence each land has on your rule and your policies. The ability to research all of the major ideas along with the minor inventions which will improve your experience. And lastly, the realistic economic management.\n\nGive it a chance and be surprised!

reviewText: A very fun strategy where the goal is to become a world power through colonization, diplomacy, and empire building. If you're not familiar with Paradox Interactive, this is another grand strategy game that takes some time to learn. However, a lot of things can be found out on your first playthrough by just pausing the game and doing a quick google search. There's nothing very difficult about the game, just a lot to learn and it ends up being very rewarding.\n\nIt's highly recommended you buy the DLC which adds much better mechanics than the base game. There's also pretty decent modding community if that's your thing.

reviewText:
Imagine a beautiful piece of music that's recorded on a potato, or a brilliant screenplay with a cast of entirely autistic people. That's what VicII is like -  an incredibly original, balanced and fun game that's just so, so deeply flawed.

Don't get me wrong, it's my favourite paradox game (or possibly my favourite game altogether) - there are no other games with this level of depth that just work so well. When everything goes right in VicII - you've made it to the 20th century, you're a great power and you're having an arms race preparing for a great war - it feels completely perfect.

I can't think of another game where the actual *gameplay* changes naturally over time. When machine guns, trench warfare and indirect fire artillery have been developed by about 1890, there's no popup saying Wars are fought statically now!". It just happens to be that to win a war after that point
date: you have to stop massing your troops into large armies and start lining them along your borders. You're not *forced* to do this
recommended: it's just that the bonuses to defence are so high that you have no choice.\n\nSimilarly
hoursPlayed: the economy and politics goes from being a trivial backwater of your country to completely dominating everything you do. By the end of the game factories are absolutely *crucial* and you'll be bending over backwards to get everything working the way you want. Politics goes from completely conservative dominated to a nightmare - by the end of the game

reviewText: Single best game I have on Steam. For anyone who enjoys PDS games (like EU, or CK) Victoria 2 is a must have. Some PDS games focus on warfare, like HoI, and because of that many of the non-warfare options can feel like tacked on complications to make war harder. Victoria 2 takes the opposite approach. You can play an entire game without fighting a single battle and yet still have a full and rich experience. If you are looking for something more than a war game, you've found it.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Paradox sucked me in with their dynastic simulator, Crusader Kings II.  My addiction deepened with the conquest-driven Europa Universalis IV.  Then I found Victoria II.  These three games each cover distinct time periods and sport their own unique gameplay.  Vicky 2 is my favorite because of the staggering amount of nation control available to play around with.  Other reviews do a better job of detailing it, but I have found the system addictively complex but never overly-complicated.  The ability to automate trade is helping me get my feet wet without overwhelming me, and I can't wait to start messing around in there either.  Already, when I go back to play the other two games, I find myself longing for the kind of internal management capabilities only found herein.  Hooked!

reviewText:
There's no game with such a strategic depth, set in the XIX century, like Victoria II.
Not only you have to carefully manage your troops, but you should also deal with factors that regards the organisation of your state and your relations: industrial power, population demands, revolutions, reforms, diplomatic relationships.

And if you get bored by all this stuff (how can you?), you can always pick a mod from the official forum. It's full of them.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
If you love strategy games buy this. I mean really, buy it now. I'll wait...

While I wait, I'll explain why I'm forcing you to buy this game. It is highly addicting once you learn the ropes. You can play as any country that existed during the 19th century. From the largest superpower... all the way down to Serbia. You control pretty much everything about your nation. You can turn it into a military powerhouse that will ♥♥♥♥ up a nation just for being looked at funny, or into an economic, peaceloving country and roll naked on piles of virtual money. There's politics, elections, trading, war, revolutions, uprising, colonies, navel arms races, world wars, annexation, and so many other fun things. Wanna have Portugal rule the world? Wanna have the South play a role through WWI? Wanna make Canada the worlds biggest navel power? You can do it in this game.

Okay enough talking from me. Buy it...

You still haven't bought it.

What if I say please?

reviewText: This game gives a fantastic insight to the industrial revolution. It's interface is unique, and it flows very smoothly with lots of features, keeping the game interesting. The developers from Paradox Interactive have done a beautifle job in terms of detail, the complexity of events and units, and the superior organization of the economy and the industry is mindblowing. All these features work very well with their highly intelligent AI in single player mode. One of the few games where the Ai actually poses as a major challenge against the player. Plunge yourself into massive wars between the great powers, or watch them destroy eachother in brutal conflicts. This game is only for the most advanced grand strategy gamers, and it requires a heavy amount of micro management to succede. 10/10

reviewText:
Very deep Paradox grand strategy game set in the Victorian era of industrialisation and railways, in which you need to manage your populace, industry and politics to ensure your empire thrives. This period was also a brutal peroid of mechanical warfare with massive established nations fighting global wars.

Although the other Paradox games like EU4 and CK2 are all unique in themselves I do find them a little bit repetitive because the gameplay a matter of witnessing new events and fighting wars, there is often not that much to do when not in conflict otherwise. CK2 has the advantage of a great intrigue system and EU4 has lovely graphics and GUI, but this Victoria 2 game has depth! It keeps you thinking on your feet all the way through to the late game and so far I have not had any time when I havent had a lot to do.

So for me Victoria 2 is the Paradox game I love the most, I think its the only game where I cant see any gameplay flaws at all, I love the era, and I love the depth of the game which is unrivalled in any strategy game I have played to date.

Watch Quill18's Japan Vic2 game on Youtube and I dare you not be be intrigued.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Victoria II is an internal management game with a (slight) military and diplomatic twist. Unlike Hearts of Iron (Warefare-based) and Europa Universalis (colonisation and exploration-based), Victoria II's focus is on domestic politics and industry.  I  like this game a lot. I like how the power structure of Great Power,teh 8 most powerful coountries in the world, Secondary Power, the the 9-16 most powerful countries, Civilized, and Uncivilized Powers, raned on if  they are westernized or not, is set up. Great powers in the game do what you'd expect a top notch colonial power, like the UK or France, to do. They can push around everyone below them. They can do whatever they want at almost any time. The secondary powers, like Mexico or Sardinia-Piedmont, can colonize and compete with the great powers at times, but cant push people around like a great power. A civilized nation, like Bolivia or Parma, are at the bottom of the civilized world. These are the countries that great powers  mostly try to fight for influence over. They may be the weakest, but some can still have a powerfull industrial and military arm compared to their regional rivals. The Uncivilized, like Oman or Siam, nations are the very bottom of the totem pole of the world's geo-political landscape. They have little power and can be pushed around quite easily (except China). Most are very weak compred to everyone else militarily and industrially. Thes countries are also at the mercy of colonization. They are also fought after by great powers.

Another thing i like is how the game makes you use different elements of your population. Each strata (farmers, craftsman, solders, etc) have a different use which are self-explanitory. a couple uses include, craftsman and clerks: they work in your factories, Beurocrats: help administration efficientcy.

The military system n the game is a bit basic, but like I said in the beginning, it's not primarily a wargame. National ideas are another thing i like because they give certain bonuses to the regions you put one in. THis game also has a decent trech tree. Different nations are better at researchng different parts of the tech tree (Prussia gets a bonus with the army and industry trees and a disadvantage with navy and culture trees).

Each game has its own pros and cons. This game, in my opinion, has pros that outway the cons.

reviewText: I've played probably over a hundred hours in non-Steam versions. Very in-depth stragety game. Unlike EU4, your actions have consequences, and is much less abstract. Things like taxation, battles, all have effects on your population (which can have their own jobs, cultures, religions, ideologies) and have them emigrate, revolt, and more. There's an in-depth economy, based on your population's jobs harvesting resources into the demands of the population and your factories.\n\nHighly recommended. Be sure to get the DLC, otherwise it's not worth your time.

reviewText: This is an excellent grand strategy game, with an ideal balance between complexity and accessibility. Of all the Paradox grand strategy games, Victoria II makes me feel most like a real, historical leader, with more methods of expansion that just military conquest, as other titles such as EU III and EU IV can feel like. The expansions are also great, with Heart of Darkness' Great War mechanic really making wars between Great Powers feel meaty and fulfilling. The game can sometimes be a little ridiculous, (such as Russia demanding Scotland as part of a peace deal with the United Kingdom, and African colonial empires often looking like random, intertwined shapes than chosive colonial territories) but the expansions again fix most of these issues with nations taking huge infamy hits for taking regions they have no claim on, and also requiring a valid reason for delaring war in the first place.\n\nOn the whole, this game feels very rewarding. Your decisons feel as though they have real concequences, and no two playthroughs are the same. The learning curve is not too steep (compared to say Hearts of Iron III), meaning a few trial games will allow you to know most of the games mechanics. In conclusion, an excellent game, still being supported by the developers, that I always come back to, despite numerous other Paradox strategy games being released since its initial relsease.

reviewText:
When I found myself as liberal Russia fighting the French fascists and communist USA in the kingdom of Mexico, I knew this was a great game.

Victoria 2 might be the only strategy game I would ever recommend to someone who doesn't like armies, navies or wars. While it can and does exist as a war game, the game also painstakingly details the political life of a country, and ties it to scientific discovery, economic growth and turmoil, and ethnic strife. The game begins in 1836--when the world is rural, religious, and disconnected. It ends in 1936, when democracy, communism and fascism are using radio and film to fight for the hearts and minds of millions of people.

Nation-states like Germany and Italy (as well as some that never existed like Scandanavia) can be formed as much by shrewd political maneuvering as by military might. Some countries like Russia, Brazil and China are very difficult to play simply because of their own internal problems, and a new player might spend much of the game fighting reactionaries and revolutionaries that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ economic and scientific growth. Other countries like France, Japan and the USA feel almost too easy, and you wonder why the USA didn't do even better than it did in real life. It also allows you to ponder vastly different (yet ostensibly possible) histories like:

-A democratic Russia
-China as a great power by 1920 with the world's largest economy
-A communist United States
-Austria forming Greater Germany
-Panjab uniting India in the late 1800s under Sikhism
-The Ottomans surviving as a federated multicutural state

...et cetera. I even revamped Liberia's infrastructure and education early on and went on to conquer half of Africa by 1910.

The biggest problem with Victoria 2 is that with so many variables that interact with one another, the game still isn't completely fine tuned. This small amount of error becomes noticeable when you have 90% of your population joining in an Anarcho-Liberal (i.e. Libertarian) uprising. The mods available on Paradox's forums fix a lot of these issues as well as revamping and adding gameplay. If you like simulators like SimCity, strategy games like Civilization, or any developments between 1836 and 1936, buy this game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: If you've found your way to this page maybe you've played some of Paradox's newer, shiner games like CK2 and EUIV and you're thinking Victoria II sounds right up my alley. Well it is. It's staggeringly complex, ridiculously fun and infinately replayable. Buy it with both expansion packs and install the POPDemand mod after you've played a few vanilla games. The mod makes this, the best Paradox strategy game possibly just the best strategy game. Do it. Do it now.

reviewText:
An extraordinary game. I questioned buying it when I first viewed it but I'm happy I did.
Here are the things I have done:
-Forced China to repay debts when playing as Canada
-Conquered most of Europe while playing as Greater Germany
-Colonized most of the Pacific as Spain and battled my way through conquering Africa
-Played as Brazil, made it to a great power and conquered a lot of South America, rivaling the US as the dominant power on the Americas
-Created an economic empire playing as the Netherlands

These are just a few I have done, and it's been a great time. I recommend buying all the DLC's except the ones priced low, as they don't add much content. I have the two major DLC's and it added a lot of worthy content.

Paradox Interactive makes great games and this is another trophy in the case.

The only con is the economic system takes a lot of time to develop and maintain.

TL;DR: This game was great and I am happy I bought it, definitely worth it!

reviewText: Victoria II is without a doubt the best Grand Strategy by the guys at Paradox. It's a pretty complex game, but once you surmount the learning curve it becomes relatively easy. Unlike Crusader Kings 2 and Europa Universalis IV (which I enjoy), this game isn't bloated by unnecessary money-grubbing DLC, and it's not geared towards casual players, while at the same time still being accessible.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: This is like the Advanced course for Paradox spergs like myself (Victoria 1 is the KILL YOURSELF NOW course fyi, fun but impossible to understand). It's the last game Paradox made before they changed their development process for CK2 so it suffers a but from the 'Old Paradox' ways of having the sequential expansions that act as patches. With Heart of Darkness, it's very good, though its one expansion away from really becoming as excellent as EU3 was and CK2 is and EU4 will be. It's based in a fascinating period of history and it's my favorite setting for a Paradox game because you can get the sense of the world shifting massively throughout the time period. From post-Napleonic squabbles over random crap, to the heyday of colonizing Africa and building railroads across the West, to the chaos and horror of the Great War and fascist/communist takeovers, Victoria covers it all. I really wish that we get a Victoria 3 of the same quality as CK2 and EU4 and that it comes with a EU4-V3 converter.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Victoria II is a game that has kept my attention for longer than almost any other game! It is very entertaining for a very long time, mainly because of the hundreds of countries you can play and the millions of ways to play them (do the math, that means a hell of a lot of different possibilities). I love watching the world shape to the different decisions both you and the other nations make.

Pros:

-Lots of fun

-Hundreds of countrys/nations to choose from

-Many varieties of government types and reforms for each one

-Detailed economy and political system

-Detailed population system

-Fun diplomacy

-Lots of good mods! Modding is easy!

Cons:

-Too many rebels/uprisings

-sometimes lags in later games during the highest speed

-long loading times (when starting the game)


All of the cons can be over looked, for instance, there is a simple mod to fix the Too many rebels problem and it is simple to download and install (PoPs of darkness). The lag doesn't really bother me too much and some people may have better computers than I have. Loading times doesn't matter too much either.

Over all it is a GREAT game and I love it!

9/10

reviewText: NOTE: The time displayed for my Victoria II playtime is actually incorrect; I've played far more than 50 hours (Steam playtime at the time of this writing). Unfortunately, I originally purchased this on the Gamestop PC App (because bargain-hunting) and Gamestop didn't offer Steam keys for it until a while after my purchase. In any case, here's the review.\n\nVictoria II is one of my favorite Paradox strategy games. It holds the distinction of being the oldest game which I continue to play, even if that is tied to its current lack of a sequel. Why, other than that, is this the game that I still play? It's hard to say, but I think that it captures its time period very well. When you build an empire in Europa Universalis, there are time periods when you have a strong sense of historical belonging, but that can't last throughout the whole game. The same can be said for Crusader Kings, which now has a ridiculously expanded timeline thanks to DLC. Victoria, on the other hand, is the Victorian Era encapsulated. Whether you dominate your foes on the mainland or discover" vast swaths of land in Africa and the Pacific
date: you feel like a Victorian leader. It's a tremendous time period to experience
recommended: and an even more tremendous time to be a European Power
hoursPlayed: or an up-and-coming uncivilized nation like Japan (which will pretty much become a Great Power whether you help it or not). I reccomend it to all strategy game fans: it's probably my favorite Paradox game... subjectively speaking."

reviewText:
This is how it will go down:

You'll buy this game.
You'll play as a Great Power, and try to conquer the world.
You'll be terrified at the game's complexity.
You'll cry.
You'll try to understand how to use it for two weeks or so.
You'll finally understand.
You'll never see your family again.

Victoria II gives you control over a nation during, well, Victorian times. If it existed in the early 19th Century, its playable. You'll control it up until just pre-WWII 20th Century (Gotta buy Hearts of Iron to play WWII, but it just won't have the same magic anyways...). What do you want to do? Stop the USA from ever getting its west coast as Mexico? You got it. Wanna play as the CSA by winning the American Civil War? Well, you better be a good commander, but you got it! Wanna ♥♥♥♥ing turn an independent Texas into a global superpower? You got it! You can also form nations. Prussia may get so much influence over its neighbors it becomes Germany. South America may unite under one flag. You can even play as an eskimo island with, like 3 people there and become a global superpower. WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? Oh, and kick some ♥♥♥ in WWI (however it happens to start in your game, and whoever the sides are) for me. Thank you.

reviewText: Victoria II is the most interesting and addicting grand strategy game that I've ever played hands down. It covers every aspect of the era. Some of those aspects including Industrialization, New Imperialism. Nationalism and the beginning of modern day revolutionist ideas and tactics. When I play Victoria II I feel a bond with the nation I'm playing. I almost develop a temporary sense of nationalism, wanting to further my nation to sitting in the #1 great power spot that it deserves to be in. If a grand strategy game can be so in depth that it makes me feel like I'm actually in the leader's position then the devolopers made this game right. This game perfectly represents the time period and also has educational value. When I played my first run as Prussia using the Historical Project Mod (I would highly recommend this mod. It completely revamps the game to more accurately represent the time period and it also improves many of the statistics and balances the game better.) I often found myself looking into the nation's history and many key decisions the leaders made to form the German Empire. Currently as I'm writing this review I have 536 hours in Victoria II and I only plan to see that number go higher as I continue to play this amazing game.

reviewText:
Victoria 2 has a lot of issues that will be a turn off for many people. For instance, it has a fairly steep learning curve. More importantly, however, is that there are too many restrictions on the player. For example, your hand is often tied by the policies of the ruling political party in your country. If a laissez faire party is running things then you’ll have to pray that your country’s capitalists think a tank factory would be profitable because you won’t be able to order one yourself. If the ruling party is pacifists then you won’t be able to pile on extra demands in your peace treaties. Also, there are too many restrictions to prevent warmongering which I disapprove of. Let us act like Napoleon or Hitler and watch the world come together to destroy us.

That being said I really like it because it handles internal politics very well and you can play as any country that existed between 1836 and 1936 (even Texas). So consider this a recommendation if you like grand strategy games.

reviewText: Victoria II is, by all standards of modern gaming, a classic. It combines the ease of use and adaptability of past Paradox games with a dynamic, mildly fast paced action on the strategic map. Tons of decisions and political choices to make, an enthrilling political system, cool classic scenarios for the time period 1836-1936 with a very fluid flow of events. I would reccomend this title to newcomers and veterans alike, as it is one rare gem of a game these days, one that keeps you interested, engaged and involved in the action both from an industrial / economical standpoint and a more political / military one. The one rule for newcomers: DONT PANIC. It will be an experience that, in time, will most certainly grant anybody a fun time in one of History's most interesting boiling points. Play one of the major factions in the world or strive for freedom as one of the smaler ones, while reforming, adapting to the shift into the modern era, or try to destroy the seemingly untouchable spread of nationalism to remain on your Imperial seat.\nWhat more do you need?

reviewText:
I previously wrote that this game would not load. I found the solution.
If you have the two major DLCs (or just one, at that), you need to download them one by one. I hadn't even downloaded the extra content for the game itself.
Step 1 - Start up the game without the two major DLCs. There should be a download.
Step 2 - Add one of the DLCs. Let it download.
Step 3 - Remove that DLC, add the other, let it download.
Step 4 - Add back both DLCs. Now you can play the game!

Good game, extremely complicated. 7/10

reviewText: hi guys i work for IGS (international Game Station) and im here to talk about the graphically intense, mind blowing first person shooter known as victoria II. i starting playing Victoria II in the early 50s right after WWII and about the time my family and i were escaping bagota to avoid religious persecution. anyway, the second i got a 360 no scope headshot i was addicted. reviewText: Victoria II, yet another masterful game from the company that dictates the Grand Strtegy" genre. This game has many realistic situations and options the allow for countless hours of gameplay. Ofter times
date: I think to myself "Where did my entire day go" while playing. Granted that overall the game is amazing
recommended:
it does have some flaws. Rebels are a serious issue that Paradox desperately needs to fix in Victoria III (if we ever get it). I'll go over some general pros and cons of this game:

PROS
-Great gameplay
-Pick any country and guide them through history (or alternate history)
-Great powers have a ton of decisions
-Easy to mod
-TONS of great/fun mods to play
-Mods patch issues with the vanilla game
-Every country offers a different expirience

CONS
-Rebels arouse too often and in way to large numbers (I've had over 3/4 of my population become rebels)
-Populations are unrealistic (China is the only country exceeding 1 million population)
-The warscore is broken (Warscore measures how well you are doing in a war and the higher it is
hoursPlayed: the better deals you can get during a peaceoffer. However
voteText:
sometimes you will be over the required warscore and the country will not surrender even if you have 100% of their provinces under your control.)
-Countries with a low starting literacy rate fall far behind in technology
-The UK never leaves the #1 spot on the country ranking
-Rebels don't make sense (for example
helpfulPercent: after you formed Germany you will get "Prussian Nationalists" which want to liberate Prussia from Germany. Historically
votesHelpful:
it was Prussia and the Prussian people who wanted to form Germany in the first place.)

***THERE ARE MODS THAT FIX A LOT OF THE CONS/ISSUES***

"

reviewText: This game is NOT for everyone; it is mind numbingly complex, rewarding careful planning. I can't say that I have played much of it yet, but I have played a lot of Hearts of Iron III as Germany, France, UK, Soviets, and the US. What I learned from HOI3 is not only is the US the player to be, but starting in 1936 is NOT early enough. That realization has led me to V2. In 1836 the US has not yet reached the goal of Manifest Destiny. The West is still wild, much of it held by Mexico. The Civil War has not been fought, and the goal that I have as the US player is to avoid it altogether. The Grand Campaign extends right through the First World War. Instead of practicing isolationist policies, I want to see the US become world cop" as soon as possible. Taking that position in HOI3 worked for me
date: and I want to see that approach work in this game. For me the biggest mistake of World War II occured in 1936 when the US and the Allies let the fascists overthrow Republican Spain. Defending Spain would have made the Allied position MUCH stronger in 1940. Similarly
recommended: avoiding the Civil War would have made the US much stronger in the next century."
hoursPlayed: April 5, 2014

reviewText: Awesome game. Gameplay is superb and it is very polished, Victoria 2 allows you to rule great and powerful empires like France, Great britain, and the US to the tiny nations of Belgium, Orangje, and Portgual. The military part of Victoria 2 is very well done with you commanding huge armies to attack a certain enemy and then annex,humiliate, or acquire lost (or gain) territory.  The politics and ecomomy part of the game is funny and interesting, as in a Communist America, Democratic Russia, and Empire of Brazil. However the AI is tough and kinda dumb, but will fight you. Overall Victoria 2 is a game you need to buy FOR $20 us dollars or 12 pounds.\n\nEdit- I recommend you get the Expansion packs A House Divided and A Heart of Darkness, both of which add even more gameplay than the base game. Also if you are going to play Multiplayer, I get and use Hamachi as the Victoria 2 Paradox servers are non- existant.

reviewText:
victoria ii is a very fun and diverse grand strategy made by paradox interactive

to put it in the most simple way possible, you choose to be any nation in the world and guide it through the victorian era and the early 1900s and basically try to grow higher in rank as much as you can

there isn't any specific goal, giving the player a lot of choice in what they want to do.
for example, if you want to form germany as austria, you can, even though it's extremely hard
if you wanna conquer canada as the united states you can do that too
you can pretty much do anything you feel like

but there's one thing i never want to see you do ever in your lifetime

never help the union win the civil war
or i will PERSONALLY FRICK FRACK UR MOM THEN KICK UR ♥♥♥

reviewText:
if your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.
Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie
Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

reviewText: This is a fantastic game to play with friends. Anyone interested interested in history, grand strategy, or even politics will enjoy the time spent playing this game. Victoria II requires a bit of work to master, the tutorials help but it really comes down to trial and error. The game doesn't attempt to hold your hand when it comes to core gameplay. Balancing a countries budget means making decisions that have wide reaching consequences and effects. Keeping a countries income positive while producing more goods than your rivals and still maintaining both an army and a navy to defend your interests is quite a challenge. All in all this is a great strategy game, if you enjoy other paradox titles you surely get some enjoyment out of it.

reviewText:
Awesome. Play it.

It's the game I've always wanted, that got me into the franchise: elections, empire building, demographic management, industrialization, international and internal politics, internal policy, reunify countries into their modern forms (such as Germany, Italy).

Here are my recommendations: Get the full version with all of the expansions (AHD and HOD) and play with one of the great community mods: GSG/Vicky or HPM

Another point is that a talented modder is making a savegame converter which already allows you to transfer your EU4 game into Victoria 2 to continue what you started in the previous games. Equally another exists to continue into Hearts of Iron 3.

Even alone however, this game is among the best.

reviewText: You can bully Holstein off of puny Denmark, round up the German minors into your sphere of influence, get Britain to help you crush Austria and snag Alsace-Lorraine off of France. Then, having formed the German Empire, you throw your hat into the ring of a crisis to give Greece some of its land back from the Ottoman empire only to find that only you and a not-so-great great power like Belgium have backed them up. One exhausting world war later, and the socialists have taken the upper legislative house. And this was just my first game! If you have the patience to weather such nuisances as Jacobin rebels, cholera epidemics, and failed botanical expeditions, then this is the industrial-era strategy game for you. Prepare to get your embassies thrown out at the drop of a hat!

reviewText:
I have yet to try other Paradox strategies, but I can already say I'm really enjoying  Victoria II	 . Before buying the steam version I had a physical copy which I got for free from a deal. It had both Victoria II + A House Divided and Victoria I + Revolutions. What made me buy the steam version was that I could not enhance the retail edition with Heart of Darkness which is a must for a full Vicky experience. I just wasn't sure if the copy of HoD I could buy was compatible with it. Go figure, I bought the steam version alongside two DLCs. No regrets.

Before you actually think of buying this or any other Paradox developed game you must take one thing into consideration.
Paradox grand strategies are known for their rather steep-learning curve  I'm looking at you, Hearts of Iron III...	 and rather confusing interface . While the tutorial might sort of give you a little pat to the right way it's possible that you may want to look up a guide on YouTube, as the former doesn't cover some important topics such as  Colonizing	 which plays a vital role in becoming a great power later on. After you know what the hell you're doing you will really enjoy this game. It's fun to lead your country becoming a contender in the ever so harsher competition for world dominance. If you're into grand strategies then this game is for you.

reviewText:
I went with the U.K for some time, appearently infamy doesn't matter with them since they are just so big of an empire that all you need to do is wait for white peace and then declare war and spread not caring about going over even 100 infamy. Evntually I satrt a new game go with U.K and play as Canada. I got anihilated by the U.S and U.K is doing nothing so I am not doing that again, unless I were to make a mod doing something about that... Well after that I tried Japan, after the first try with them I had Korea and parts of Arabia, then stopped playing Japan for whatever reason. Then I tried Siam, I got beaten by the Chinese for expanding right next to them.

Then I try South America because Risk logic. Argentina, Chile, and Brazil are so good in my opinion. Now playing as these countries I ought to pay attention to Infamy since the one time I was Brazil and went too far then everyone declares war on me, never played Brazil again. So Argentina ends up being my favourite country and is the first thing I mod and I made infamy nothing to worry about by giving me cores, and then I formed a new nation just because mods, flags never work in my mods for some amount of reasons. Well I end up being a nation that has the lands of Argentina, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay, and poor ol' Bolivia. I remember the one time I made a game allied with everyone in South America except for Bolivia and made a non-reasonable crusade against them, five years later I just annex them then betray just about everyone in the south of South America.

Now I have tried Mexico a few times and none of the times have I succesfully taken Texas, one time I have complete control over Texas but then U.S interferes nearly last second, I really want to make mods that will make the U.S not so full of military power. Also the only reason why I would ever suport C.S.A.

Well this is my experience on the game but to make this an actual review, the game isn't all world domination like I originally thought, no instead you wait for Cassus-Belli I think it's called and then you decide if you want to declare war without gaining infamy, or go ahead and get infamy it's really up to you. Being a Great Power gives you a great advantage when it comes to diplomacy, sometimes it can be fun to get a lot of money coming in and just looking through the wars supporting whichever side by giving war subsidies. Sometimes it's hard to industrialize most likely because you're political party won't pay for building factories, well if your a HM government you can change to some party that will let you or somehow get a revolt and change governments that way. It can be fun colonising but the French are just too quick with colonising in my opinion. Playing as a low country can be fun as a challenge yet it is frustrating, especially when some country annihilates your only hopes of winning wars. Encouragement is useful yet I feel as if it is something barely thought of.

Well that's pretty much all, my advice would be if you're going against an uncivilized nation or country, whatever. Check if any Great Power has friendly relations with them or has them in sphere, now if none do and you are not going to wait for a Cassus-Belli or you know you are not going to since I so far only get those by border incidents then declare war through demand concession" way less infamy given. There is also demand protectorate or something

reviewText: Kings of Strategy, Paradox Interactive's late modern era game. Historical events and options are plentiful. A shorter timespan than most PI games, only 100 years, from 1836 to 1936, as opposed to the four centuries that Crusader Kings and Europa Universalis have. Starting just at the rise of Pax Britannica, just after the falls of the French and Spanish Empires, there's so much to do in this game. Form the German Empire. Try and stay an Absolute Monarchy through the rise of Liberalism, Socialism, Communism and Fascism. Act out America's Manifest Destiny and partake in the Civil War. Play the Chinese Empire and try and modernise and resist foreign influences. Play the Ottoman Empire and prevent your backslide into historical obscurity. There's so much to do, and you've got to make your own goals. In usual Paradox style there's a ton of super-complex systems that you need to know, but if you get a handle on it, there's so much depth and replayabilitiy to be done.

reviewText: Since Steam doesn´t allow anything els but clear thumbs down or up, i´ll have to settle for a thumb down. Why? A solution can be easily found, so you might wonder why this  would suffice to give a thumb down for an otherwise very good game.\nThe answer:\nThis ctd has been known for at least four years now and has still not been fixed by paradox. I should not have to fix some unavoidable ctd straight after purchasing a game and this has in fact been the only game (with 80 in the library) where I ever experienced something like this. Some of my games are even as old as Iám myself, yet non caused such a hassle.

reviewText: I had high hopes for Vicky 2, since CK2 and EU4 are pretty solid games.  Vicky 2 is great when it comes to the economic build up and the complexities of Great Power diplomacy, but it falls (extremely) when military and basic AI comes into the fray.  Military is very messy and unorganized, something that I was surprised to see in a Pdox game.  I have heard players say it is micromanagement, but it isn't.  It comes down to very bad game design right down to the UI.  It is no wonder why the series hasn't had any rumors of a sequel since this was poorly executed.  If  a Vicky 3 ever arrives (unlikely) then I hope it takes cues from the solid vision from EU4.

reviewText:
This game is good, but only on the hands of the patient ones.

I'm beginner at Paradox games, first is EU3, and I'm good at it. I try Victoria 2, and it is bad. Bad not as in bad gameplay but bad as in my inability to fully understand the trading and production system of Victoria 2. Sure, there is tutorial, but it is still not enough for me. And then there's the fact that there is no Steam Workshop, which is understandable as Victoria 2 is an old game and its fanbase (according to my own opinion) is not as huge as Crusader Kings or Europa Universalis.

I want to recommend this game, but in the end, I just can't.

reviewText:
I'd like to give Victoria 2 a positive review, but at this time, I just cannot bring myself to do so.

Positives of the game in my eyes:
-Economics are fantastic-If you like EU4, but want a deeper level of economics, then this game certainly fills that role perfectly.
-Colonization is fun-Pretty self explanitory here. Competing with other great powers for the rich coast of Africa is a fun contest of will and strength.
-Taking a nation from civilized" to "Great Power" is amazing-I took Japan and made it into a great power
date:
easily overpowering Spain and the USA in the conquest of China.

Negatives of the game in my eyes:
-Horrible amount of popup events-I understand that you get random events
hoursPlayed: but when you get the same dang event popping up fifty-seven times in twenty minutes
voteText: it makes for a lousy impression. I've heard that its due to some of the DLCs
helpfulPercent: but that's still no excuse for this to occur so often.\n-Great powers gang up- You can be helping the smallest of nations with some small war
votesHelpful: and suddenly you'll find yourself facing the UK and bloody every other great power on Earth for no other reason than the fact that you're at war. Others may find this realistic
votesTotal: I find it annoying
votesFunny: especially if I'm the one being attacked by the smaller nation.\n-Literacy rate makes or breaks you-I realize that I do not yet quite understand the full concept of literacy in Victoria 2
commentsCount: but I hate that you can have a full education budget and dedicate all of your resources to try and build up the literate people
column16: but it will still take you decades (and often longer) to go up a few percentage points.\n-Unstable game-Pretty self explanitory. This game crashes every so often
column17: though it the biggest complaint with this is that mods cause it to crash like a boss.\n\nAfter all is said and done
column18: do I regret buying this game? No
column20: I do think that you should ask yourself if you like grand strategy games and if you are willing to look past the flaws. It can be a really fun experiance
column21: but you'll have to not get annoyed at the crashes or the endless popup events."
