reviewText:
Keep in mind that I have no DLC or Mods. At first the game was very fun. You can play as every faction on the map, you conquor, enlist generals, engage in politics and tech, the list goes on. I've never completed a campaign.. which begins the bad things about the game for my HP 2000 Notebook PC:

My first campaign was as Ethiopia, very fun and attacking egypt in the South while the  Ottomans from the North. After the war was over and egypt was now a minor power, I decided to save my game and exit. The next day I load up the game and select Ethiopia to continue... crash. After trying to fix it, every time I select my save slot, it crashes... Well there goes an hour of post-napoleonic fun.. I start one as japan, three days later when I load it up.. same frustration with Ethiopia. As time passes and I keep loading up different factions, some time sooner or later.. crash!

I wouldn't spend my money on the DLC when I don't know if it'll still crash. If you get the game while on sale, like I did, then you won't be as mad.

My rating is 5/10 on sale, 4/10 for full price.. might as well use that for Europa IV

reviewText: To start off, I don't normaly complain about games, and playing games such as CK2 and EU4 I was expecting a great game from Paradox. I paid £15 for the base game, but when I started playing I found there was barely anything in the game. It was like EU4 but with only the basic features. So, I thought I would pay the extra £15 for the Hearts of Darkness expansion, but when it downloaded the DLC, the launcher wouldn't launch. I then deleted the game and re-downloaded but it did the same. I restarted my computer then deleated the game, re-downloaded and realunched. The launcher worked and I happily clicked play. I then discovered that you need A House Divided to play. A game I wanted to play for £15 will end up costing me over twice as much and even then it still might not work. The thing that annoyed me was that steam said you could play HOD without AHD.\n\nIF YOU WANT TO BUY, BUY IN A STEAM SALE. DONT BUY IN SEPERATE PARTS!

reviewText:
Do you feel like watching 4 hours of tutorials and reading guides for another 2?  If so, this game is for you!

I normally wouldn't complain about investing the time to play a game... if the game actually paid off.  I found myself bored quickly bored.  There are several other games that have much better mechanics and keep game play interesting.  This is not Sid Meiers Civilization -- and in my opinion that would be the game to recommend.

When I compare this to other strategy games, I see how the developers tried really hard, tried to add an original spin on things, and failed, failed, failed.  I suppose it's an honest effort compared to franchises that have bigger budgets to work with.  I really think this game could have been great if it were more intuitive, quicker paced with better action/events, and threw in some cut scenes and an expanded diplomatic section.

The basic plot is to play as any country in the Victorian era.  The game really centers around the big powers of the day -- Britain, Russia, Germany, and a few others including America.  The game seems built to cater to players who will automatically pick a big power.  If, however, you pick a smaller or less influential country -- game play is like eating dry toast.

There is a research system for national focus" which lets you open up new technology and discoveries.  The options are well-thought out and historically appropriate.  The major flaw is the slow speed to finish one item of research.  I don't see how anyone can unlock and achieve all the national focus items even at the drawn-out slow pace of the game.  If we are being realistic
date: 2015 would not be 2015 as we know and live in it if it were based on the research portion.  So... fail.  Perhaps

I suppose this is somewhat.... somewhat... realistic

There are some unique aspects to the mechanics of the game such as population militancy and choices that advance or curtial liberlism.  I am sure if I had more time to let my eyes glaze over waiting for something to happen

reviewText:
I went through the tutorials and really liked the aspects of this game except for two things... army recruitment and declaring war.

Both of these aspects are terrible. You can't just conscript/train soldiers - you have to convince your population that the career of a soldier is right for them. This increases the pool of soldiers from which you can field and later reinforce brigades.

You can't declare war when you want to. You have to justify it, which takes time. Extremely annoying. All in all it's pretty crippling if you're wanting to invade your neighbors.

reviewText: The multiplayer (or lack of) absolutely ruins an otherwise decent strategy game. Single player can only be fun for so long, even with mods, before the mounting desire to play with friends gets the best of one. At this point you'll find it is impossible to play multiplayer because Paradox Interactive is incapable of writing halfway decent network code. This is evident in the fact that they thankfully switch to the Steam service with their newer games.\n\nIn conclusion, if Johan wasn't so busy grubbing for shekels with all his DLC he could actually make decent games with working multiplayer. But hey, the Swedes love your money.

reviewText: Victoria II isn't so much a game as an alternate history simulator.  The designers were obsessive about their historical accuracy and detail... they just forgot to design any significant gameplay around it.  There are quite a few nations you can play as, but unless you play as one of the 8 great world powers, your gameplay will consist of watching your country run itself and making small insiginificant nudges in certain directions until you get invaded by one of the 8 great world powers.\n\nIn summary, if you love obscure history and games that play themselves, you'll love Victoria II.

reviewText:
Vicky 2 is an interesting game.

Covering roughly the early/mid 19th century up into the early 20th, this Paradox helping is part Europa Universalis and part Hearts of Iron but mostly something entirely different from anything else the developer has put out there.

Just like the actual historical period which it covers, Vicky 2 is more or less all about industrialization and the dramatic changes taking place in the realms of technology, philosophy, politics, and culture across the globe.

That being said much of the game's focus is firmly set on the domestic and the player's ability to effectively manage and build upon their chosen country's economy and government - dealing with the challenges laid before them by foreign powers or groups within the nation-state itself.

Despite being fairly in line with Paradox's other grand strategy games I just couldn't quite get into this one and I doubt most others will as well.

reviewText:
I recalled the pleasure of Victoria Revolutions from sometime back. Used to play a lot of LAN games with a friend. Now it is on online, no more LAN for us.

So when I buy a game that says it is multiplayer, and I live in the 21st century, I am sorely disappointed when that game requires me to use some third party software to be able to play multiplayer games. I do not care to learn whatever software is needed for a work around just to play a game that should have the functionality.

The dated graphics also do the game no favors.

Even a 5.00 on sale I feel like I was ripped off on this multiplayer game. A crying shame since there are so few games covering the period.

Might be fun solo, but I game to be social with friends who no longer live nearby.

reviewText:
This was my first Paradox game.  Well, technically the demo of this was my first Paradox game - a demo in which I put in about 100 hours (even though you could only play as the US).

Victoria II has aged pretty well, although it is not as new as Crusader Kings II or EU IV.  There's a bit of a steep learning curve, but you don't need to know everything to start having fun with the game (and it's not *as* bad as some games).  The game is fairly balanced and bug-free - at least for a grand strategy game with a horrifyingly elaborate economy and political system (how about modeling everybody in the whole wide world for 100 years? Yes, it's that horrifying).  Both expansions are recommended - this was before the switch to modular DLCs, and both expansions are BIG changes and expansions to game mechanics.

You can play as any nation in the world from 1836 to 1936, an era of colonization, unprecedented technological change, and a lot of geopolitical bureaucratising.  If slowly going Bismark over diplomatic struggles, exploiting crises to launch terrible world wars, or carving out continents for economic and political sway appeals to you - this is your game.

reviewText:
Victoria II is a very niche game in my opinion. This is not for everyone. The combat is basically a combination of luck and stats and is very frustrating so don't come into this game expecting anything like StarCraft.

As an avid lover of history though this is basically my wet dream come true. Victoria II focuses on the Post Napoleon Era of the world. This game allows you to play as basically everything country that existed between the early 19th century and the 1920s. I have never seen a game that allowed me to play as Belgium or Colombia or Hawaii. The point is to take your country from an early industrial state to being an imperial empire.

You have to build your nation, your economy, your foreign relations, and your military. Either hope to be one of the eight main superpowers or pray to at least maintain your independence. What it most interesting is that there doesn't seem to be a way to actually lose". When my government was overthrown I thought I lost
date: but the game kept going. Except we were communists and new social policies were in place and my ecomony was wrecked from the civil war. Which is interesting mechanic. The objective is to be the top great power and you are competing with over a 100 other nations that may come and go. Mods add even more.\n\nVictoria II works for me because I like the management aspect and it focuses on my favorite era of history and allows me to play anywhere in the world. I have to plan my economy and expansion and go to war carefully since it can cost you prestige
recommended: cost you a portion of your workforce if they get slaughtered
hoursPlayed: and drain your economy (like a real nation).\n\nIt's not a perfect game
voteText: but I have fun and maybe you will too."

reviewText:
One of the best grand strategy games i've ever played.

I constantly come back to this once or twice a year and get 50-60 hours out of it everytime.  The only downside like most Paradox Interactive games is the learning curve.  You'll spend several and I mean serveral hours learning how to do everything, what every chart means (where every chart is), what all the stats mean etc.. but once you do, you'll be hooked.

You'll take control of any nation that existed in the world in the year of 1836 (or 1861 with some DLC) and shape their future until the start of the 2nd World War..... You'll do this with war, diplomacy and industrial power...

Stop Germany from ever getting formed... as the US why stop with just colonizing the west during the manifest destiny.. why not take all of mexico?  Or even play as the Zulu and make sure the English never get a true foot hold in south africa..  very very fun to reshape or shape the history the way you choose....

reviewText:
I think this is a good game and I recommend it. That being said, it has some extremely annoying features.

First off, I hate late game combat. Good combat, in my opinion is when there are two great powers with more or less equal armies that attack each other. That combat I love, early and mid game combat is really fun and challenging. But once chemical warfare has been invented and level five forts are built, forget it. Do you want to take over a single region of a tiny country that has one brigade? Too ♥♥♥♥ing bad. You know why? Because they built max level forts in every single one of there regions and also mobilized there forces so they have twenty billion brigades now. Oh, and not to mention they are allied with every single nation in the entire game. But thats just little countries. Not being able to take over other small civilized nations is fine, I can live with it, but combat is just not fun fighting anything at all. I mean, god damn its so pointlessly slow and painfully frustrating. For example, I was fighting against Italy as Germany. As Germany, I had conqured Austria, Bohemia and Morovia, as well as totally dismantled the Austrian Empire by freeing Hungary and Slovenia. So Austria was gone, and it was about 1930 in game. Italy had a much weaker army that I did, and they were fighting to defend Switzerland. They had tiny populations in comparison to mine. I sent my entire army, of over 300 brigades, against my enemies who had a few armies of about 14. I sent some boats around to blockade Italy, and in doing so, it was revealed that that was the extent of there armies. Alright, this will be over quick. Right? I send a eighty four brigades against the puny Swiss army of 14, while I waited in the border regions for Italy to make there move. It literally takes months of ingame fighting to actually beat the army, and in doing so I lost thousands of men, while the Swiss army came out relativly unscathed. Yes, yes indeed, the Swiss army takes almost no casulaties against a gigantic army of death. Oh, and did I mention they just spammed infantry while my entire army was composed of guards, artillery, tanks, and planes? I also had all military techs researched. In the meantime, Italy mobalized there forces and are now pulling huge stacks of 60 brigades out of there ♥♥♥♥. So, thats fine, I have armies of 14 brigades all along the border with level 5-6 forts. They send their armies to attack mine, and the only way I can possibly beat them is if I grossly outnumber them, and they are attacking me on fortified regions. Oh right, they were also spamming infantry. And all of my armies were composed of the most advanced possible units. Every single god damn battle takes so damn long, and EVERY SINGLE TIME I can't kill any of the enemy! Its so futile, everytime I manage to kill any brigade, two more take its place! So even with the largest and most advanced army in the entire world, I can't beat two ♥♥♥♥ tier nations spamming infantry. Meanwhile in Switzerland I keep beating them (because I outnumber them three two one) and I just can't.. kill them. I just can't. I literally CAN'T KILL ANY OF THEM. They just run off to there other region and regenerate there army in ten seconds and go back to one of the captured regions. It is immensly frustrating. And it doesn't help that every square inch of Switzerland and Northern Italy is covered with maxed out level forts. Not that I could go on the offensive at all. I couldn't beat there god damn infantry stacks on my own fort covered land, let alone theirs. It just feels like you never make any real progress, you know? Like your just stuck. So ♥♥♥♥ the combat in this game.

The other really annoying thing about this game is the diplomacy. The diplomacy system makes sense, but its still pretty obnoxious. If you are in dire need of allies, and are preparing for war (say, when I was playing as the North German Fed. and was preparing war against Austria) their are no allies to be found. No one wants to ally with you. Ever. Except the stupid Ottomans, who are totally useless. But when you are all bloated with income and military strength, having the most powerful army in the world and have taken over Austria, every nation is falling over themselves to get allied with me. Oh, NOW you want an alliance Russia, now that I am Germany? Yeah, well I didn't get here thanks to you.

My other qualm with this game is the popups. The popups in this game are notorious, and for good reason. Usually, they aren't too bad during peacetime. Just a little annoying. But god damn they ♥♥♥♥ me off when I am micromanaging armies in a heated war. Every single time with the popups. You want to send an army into New Mexico? Well, you see, you can't because, this old guy bought a tractor up in Bualsville. So you know, pretty sweet right? Okay. Just wanted you to know. ♥♥♥♥. No, I don't care that old man Johnson bought a tractor, no I don't care that there's liberal agitation in Inverness, and NO I don't care that the upperhouse was rearranged and the reactionaries lost .17 percent of seats. Even still, I can handle the popups. The only time when I really, just can't stand them is during the elections. I'm sorry, are there too many popups? Here have some more. And this one literally obscures the entire middle part of the map!

My finaly issue is rebellions. They happen all the time, repetedly and without end. Even when it says militancy is going down, ITS LIEING. It goes up no matter what! They might as well have just taken out the militancy meter and just had scripted rebellions every five minutes or so. It might just be because I never reform to allow voting (♥♥♥♥ing popups), but god its annoying. It makes the game almost unplayable. Luckily, its a very easy thing to fix with mods, so you can just do it yourself. But in vanilla, sheesh, they never end.

All this is outweighed by the good in the game. The best part about this game is.. well, being successful. Watching as your economy explodes, as a never ending stream of factories are built all over your nation and your population booms to meet the growing demand. Or seeing your entire border bristle with forts and the most advanced brigades. Or basking in the never ending flow of money. Or see as your nation grows bigger and stronger as it takes over more and more regions. As it evolves from humble begannings as a uncivilized nation to a superpower that dominates the world. Having a colonial empire that streches from Kenya to Arabia. Which.. well, thats not really that big. I usually don't go for colonies in this game. But man, you COULD have colonies that stretch from Cape Town to Singapore (like the real life British Empire). So like any game, it terrible when you are losing and is great when you win. All in all, I spend over fifty hours in this game, so I recommend it fully.

reviewText:
Overall though I found the game enjoyable. There were only a few things that I found annoying (which are corrected in newer Paradox games).

I played this game as the US and spent a large portion of my time at speed 5. One of the greatest changes between Victoria II and EU4 or CK2 is the ability to hide messages. I don't care that a certain county now has a nitroglycerin or the Copperheads are planning something, there's no reason that a dictator/president would be given that sort of information. Definitely need to know when someone's declared war on me, but otherwise, I find a lot of the popups to be annoying.

The amount of rebellions was also extremely annoying. I know I'm playing the US and the CSA is formed, but I spent most of the Civil War fighting the Jacobite (and several other) rebels into submission. Although the Civil War began in ~1858 I didn't finally put the nail in the coffin until 1872.

The election part of the game was interesting as it allows the player to manipulate who is going to win the election with no downside fo them.

I am certainly still a noob at this game and will probably put in another 20 or so hours to at least learn the game.

tl;dr: I enjoyed this game and will carry on playing. Unfortunately, my friends suck and don't like these games, but I continue to recommend them on deaf ears 8/10.

reviewText: Begining in the early 19th century, the game lets you choose any country that was in the world at that time to play as. *8/10

-Pros

In-depth grand campaign with actual historical events represented (both mundane and important).

Many options for ruling your Empire. Be it with the pen or the sword.

-Cons (Not easy to find cons)

Overall, well worth the sale price.

reviewText:
(Note: even though Steam says I have less then 1 hour played in this game, that is incorrect, as I have several hundred hours played, I just don't use Steam when playing)

Victoria 2 is probably one of the best but most complicated strategy games ever made. The sheer scale and scope of it will blow your mind if you haven't played a Paradox game before (actually it still will even if you have). But once you start to understand its systems and the time period, your mind will really be expanded. The politics system and the economics alone are more detailed, realistic and complex than anything outside of a high-level supercomputer simulation (and certainly more so then any other game I know of).

It is daunting to learn the complexity of this game, but fortunately you don't really need to master all the systems in order to be able to play fairly well (you can get-by without understanding everything). And the more you play the more you'll master it and, like I said, by the time you've done that you will literally be a smarter person. The game's mechanics are complex enough that you cannot really predict the outcome of things in the long run (like which countries will come to dominate), because it's all based on complex systems interactive with other complex systems to create the ultimate complexity. Which does a good job of simulating human history,

The vanilla game is good, but it gets much better with mods. Of which there are lots. There's tweak mods, overhaul mods, alternate history mods, etc. But the one I would recommend for both improved gameplay and improved realism is POP Demand Mod (it's probably the closest you'll get to actually directing history).

This is a game where you take a nation from the 19th century, very much into the 20th. You can industrialise as an advanced European colonial power, or start as a primitive country (like say China or Japan) and if you play right, you can race ahead and catch up and even overtake the Europeans. By the end of a game you're likely to be in a very interesting world, with Monarchies, Democracies, Fascist and Communist states fighting it out in world wars. You will never have the same end-game world in more than one playthrough, so you're creating alternate history as you go.

If you're into hardcore strategy and/or history, then you've got to experience this game.
